mainTopic.title: Opioids
mainTopic.content_info: The lecture handouts come with a lot of detailed information that is sufficient to cover the whole topic

quizzes.question: What are opioids and how are they structurally related to morphine?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Opioids are natural or synthetic compounds with morphine-like properties; they are structurally related to morphine by having up to 5 distinctive rings.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Opioids are synthetic compounds only and have no structural relation to morphine.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Opioids have no specific structure and are created through random synthesis.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Opioids are always derived from codeine and have 3 distinctive rings.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Opioids have no relation to morphine and do not possess any ring structure.

quizzes.question: How does replacing the N-methyl group in morphine affect its properties?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Replacing the N-methyl group with larger groups like allyl often creates opioid antagonists.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Replacing the N-methyl group enhances agonist activity and potency.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Replacing the N-methyl group turns it into a non-opioid substance.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: The N-methyl group replacement has no effect on opioid properties.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Replacing the N-methyl group causes the compound to lose all opioid activity.

quizzes.question: On what basis are opioids classified into agonists, antagonists, and mixed agonist-antagonists?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Opioids are classified based on their interaction with receptor subtypes like µ, κ, and δ.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Opioid classification is based solely on their natural or synthetic origin.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Opioids are classified based on their color and taste.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Classification is based on the speed of action.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Opioids are classified based on patient preferences.

quizzes.question: What characterizes opioid agonists?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Opioid agonists have high affinity and activity at opioid receptors to provide analgesia.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Opioid agonists only block opioid receptors and prevent any response.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Opioid agonists have no effect on any receptor types.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Agonists decrease the synthesis of enkephalins in the body.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Agonists work by stimulating the metabolism of codeine.

quizzes.question: What are enkephalins and what role do they play in the body?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Enkephalins are endogenous opioids that modulate neurotransmitter release and are selective for δ receptors.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Enkephalins are dietary supplements with no role in neurotransmitter modulation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: They are synthetic drugs that inhibit all neurotransmitter activity.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Enkephalins are enzymes that degrade neurotransmitters.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: They serve solely as structural proteins in neurons.

quizzes.question: Which endogenous opioid peptide is derived from proopiomelanocortin (POMC)?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Endorphins, chiefly β-endorphin, are derived from POMC.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Only enkephalins are derived from POMC.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Dynorphins are solely derived from POMC.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: All opioid peptides are derived from dopamine.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: α-endorphins, which don't exist, are derived from POMC.

subTopics.title: Pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of opioid agonists

quizzes.question: How do opioids produce analgesic effects in the central nervous system?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Opioids inhibit adenylyl cyclase, modulate receptor-ion interactions, and alter neurotransmitter release specific to pain pathways.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Opioids enhance serotonin uptake exclusively to provide analgesia.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: They act solely by causing vasoconstriction in the brain.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Opioids increase the production of adrenaline to relieve pain.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: They work by directly stimulating pain receptors.

quizzes.question: What is the role of adenylyl cyclase in opioid pharmacodynamics?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Opioids inhibit adenylyl cyclase, leading to decreased cAMP and modulation of pain signaling.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Adenylyl cyclase is stimulated by opioids to enhance pain transmission.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: It is unaffected by opioids and plays no role in their pharmacodynamics.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Adenylyl cyclase causes vasodilation in response to opioids.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Opioids use adenylyl cyclase to increase blood glucose levels.

quizzes.question: How do opioid antagonists like naloxone work?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Naloxone is a pure antagonist that competitively binds to µ, κ, and δ receptors to reverse opioid effects.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Naloxone binds with high affinity to blood lipids, enhancing opioid effects.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Naloxone only binds to δ receptors and enhances opioid analgesia.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Naloxone promotes the production of more endogenous opioids in the body.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: It inhibits all neural activity, not specific to opioid receptors.

quizzes.question: What are the characteristics of opioid agonist-antagonists?
quizzes.goodAnswer: They have both analgesic properties and the ability to antagonize the effects of pure opioid agonists.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: They solely bind to peripheral nerves to treat inflammation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Agonist-antagonists amplify the effects of opioid withdrawal.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: They mimic all effects of opioids without any antagonist activity.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Agonist-antagonists enhance digestion and have no effect on pain.
